title: Rob Brydon webchat â as it happened | Stage | The Guardian
summary: `` i 've done so much stuff in my career that 's flying by the seat of my pants ''
`` i did n't get where i am today without randomly posting a general inquiry in the hope that i 'll get and featured in the guardian ''
`` i 'd like to still be working , still making people laugh [ at 77 ] . and not to have succumbed to age-related memory loss . and to still be working , still making people laugh ''
`` of the people around today , there are none i have any regard or respect for ''
`` whether under or over the water , it 's got to be breast ''

documents.title: that 's it for today !
text: thanks very much for all your questions , and to rob for joining us and answering as many as he could .
cheers !
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 4:07pm thank you guardian readers , i 've enjoyed that immensely .
i 'm now going back to rehearsals for future conditional at the old vic .
previews currently running , press night thursday 10th .
i hope you 'll like it .
athanadler82 asks : does your relentlessly affable on screen persona mean people feel they can approach you ; is this cloying ?
has anyone ever done a rob brydon impression at you ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 4:06pm yes .
no .
only harry enfield 's friend .
lucid11 asks : i really enjoyed your performance as stanislas frã©ron in bbc 's heroes and villains .
i actually think his character upstaged napoleon every time they shared screen time .
the whole program was a piece of television that looked like it belonged in the cinema .
how did you feel being a comedian equipped you to play a character like him , a villain that was a bit more contemplative than most ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 4:05pm finally , someone who saw it !
so glad you liked it .
i thought it would lead to other villains , but alas , affability won through .
in answer to your second question , i do n't know .
elenacresci says : alright , how 's it going , alright ?
just wanted to say cheers for making my life 10x easier at university everyone knew where barry was by then , thanks to gavin and stacey .
are you glad you played uncle bryn ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 4:03pm absolutely .
loved the part , loved the show , love ruth , love james .
it was a joy from start to finish .
and people seem to love it as much now as they ever did .
i get asked about it all the time , and it 's very pleasing to see someone 's face light up if i become uncle bryn in front of them , `` and i 'll tell you for why ``
damian petts asks : saw you on television at l'enclume , what 's your favourite restaurant and food and do you like cockles ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 4:01pm along with il riccio , see earlier answer , i love le manoir aux quat'saisons .
great food , great service , and if you stay overnight who knows what could happen ?

documents.title: `` i 've done so much stuff in my career that 's flying by the seat of my pants ''
text: id4192684 asks : do you feel any pressure headlining the first show at the old vic under matthew warchus 's reign ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:59pm not really , no .
here 's the thing : i 've done so much stuff in my career that 's flying by the seat of my pants .
when i did my first marion and geoff live show at the ambassadors in london , i went out to perform the second half having never done it in front of an audience before .
in the dressing room in the interval i was almost catatonic with fear .
i could n't speak .
many of the comedy gigs i 've done , i 've not known what i 'm going to say before i get out there .
by comparison , the world of theatre allows you so much preparation that it 's a very different sensation .
you reach a point in rehearsals when you yearn for an audience to see it and give their response .
on this production in particular , it 's very clear that i 'm in remarkably safe hands in the form of matthew and the team he has around him .
they seem to know what they 're doing .
tonyjoe asks : is there a tiny part of you that believes it when lee mack and david mitchell joke about not liking you ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:53pm you ca n't see this but that 's made me laugh very loudly !
thank you .
dinamarca asks : how do you stand on sexist jokes in the vain of jimmy carr or even yourself ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:52pm in jokes as in life , it 's not what you do , it 's the way that you do it .
hardabit asks : cravat or neckerchief ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:51pm omid djalili bought me two cravats for my birthday .
i 've yet to pluck up the courage to wear them .

thethoughtfox asks : did you have any input into the change of tack in the second trip show , in which you were less of a sidekick to steve and more confident , forthright and , it seemed to me , free to be pushing the comedy rather than reacting to it ?
it seemed that the relationship , or the dynamics of it , had changed , both to the advantage of your character and the show itself .
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:49pm yes .
it was a decision that the three of us came to - it certainly made it more interesting for me .
having said that , i do n't mind playing the sidekick role , i 'm just interested in comic dynamics and playing them to the best of my ability .
it 's a very rich seam to mine .
i think of jeffrey tambor , charles grodin - they do that kind of stuff so well .

documents.title: `` i did n't get where i am today without randomly posting a general inquiry in the hope that i 'll get and featured in the guardian ''
text: dubinmadrid says : hi rob !
love your work .
i have no question except : how are you ?
and am only posting here in the hopes that i 'll get and featured in the guardian newspaper .
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:47pm i like you attitude .
i did n't get where i am today without randomly posting a general inquiry in the hope that i 'll get and feature in the guardian newspaper .
neither mrs cj nor i got where we are today without randomly posting a general inquiry in the hope that i 'll get and feature in the guardian newspaper .
rip david nobbs .
what a lovely and talented man .
he came to see me in a chorus of disapproval and i slipped in an `` i did n't get where i am today '' for his benefit .
do n't tell ayckbourn
pooka1986 asks : is stage acting something you feel more suited to as you 're a trained actor ?
are you making up for lost time ?
you admire so many greats burton , hopkins , pacino ( and do very good impressions of them ) are you going to follow their suit more and continue with stage work ?
you played kenneth tynan ; was that a hint that you wanted to head for somewhere like the old vic ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:45pm i love being on the stage , but the truth is i have a big family and it kind of gets in the way of home life , being out all the time .
future conditional is a short run , as is the painkiller which i 'm doing next year at the garrick .
i never saw burton on the stage , but i saw hopkins in pravda and m butterfly - he was of course mesmerising .
and i saw pacino on broadway in the merchant of venice .
enormous hands .
maanuv asks : how have you found working with matthew warchus at the old vic , and what was the rehearsal room like for future conditional ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:43pm hugely impressed by matthew .
i did n't realise how many of his plays i 'd seen .
i watch him in the rehearsal room making decisions , little changes , and sit there thinking : oh yes of course !
that 's how it should be he 's also in the running for calmest man on earth .
which i like .
martingore asks : our amdram group did chorus of disapproval recently , with a scot trying to do dafydd .
i saw you in london and you were awesome in the role .
any anecdotes to share ?
i played hapless ted .
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:41pm never mind your question , `` awesome in the role '' , you say ?
mmmm that 's right yes
isabellablue asks : at what moment were you absolutely certain you project a sexier image than steve coogan , and how often have you brought this to his attention ?
did he cry , play it down or wear it like a man ?
oops , multiple questions there !
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:40pm oh god , i hope he does n't read this .
alexjarman asks : in siena at the palio over a decade back , i once enquired as to you how your little smashers were from across the crowded track .
did you ignore me because you did n't hear me , or did you think i was just a twat ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:39pm i think you know the answer to that .
fizzlebangwonderpop asks : are you still championing the longer sock , or have you come to your senses ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:38pm yes , though not quite as zealously as i once did .

jervillian asks : charlotte church : concerned , laudable citizen taking advantage of her celebrity in a meaningful and fearless way to get a crucial message to the forefront of media discussion ; or silly , attention-seeking bint ?
remember , according to guardian commentators , there are only these two extremes .
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:35pm the former , surely ?
piltrafilla says : hello rob .
i ca n't look at a kumquat without thinking of you .
forever yours .
xx guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:35pm can i be serious for a moment ?
that 's so nice to hear .
when you do these things , you hope they chime with people .
i remember when we were doing that scene , we were both drunk , and i was laughing my head off .
it 's such a stupid joke , but i love it .
also , loved getting to reference gore vidal , someone i would have loved to meet .
eyez2c asks : lee mack or david mitchell if it was one or the other whose show/work would you part money with to go and see ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:33pm both of them .
i know it 's annoying but we get on remarkably well .
i see quite a bit of lee , we live near each other .
some of my funniest nights in recent memory have been spent in his company .
david lives further away and for this reason , and this reason alone , i see less of him .
he is however always in my thoughts .
pitinerant asks : i 'm currently sitting in an office bored out my mind , the walls are magnolia and the desk is pine , where am i ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:31pm in a hell of your own making .

documents.title: `` whether under or over the water , it 's got to be breast ''
text: george rout asks : what is your favourite swimming stroke ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:30pm breast .
every time .
whether under or over water , it simply does n't matter it 's got to be breast .
having said that , front crawl is another one i 've enjoyed over the years .
like most men of my age , i 've attempted the butterfly .
once .
tom hughes asks : is midnight run still your favourite film ?
is red your name ?
do you dye your hair ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:29pm it 's one of my favourites certainly , it 's joyous .
a lot of the trip for me is inspired by charles grodin and his relationship dynamic with bobby .
no , i 've never met him .
blibbka asks : where can i watch the hilarious take you did on who do you think you are again ?
not online , on youtube , zilch !
flatfrog blibbka asks : the whole series of annually retentive was a bit of a forgotten gem .
it passed me by for years because it looked so much like the kind of interchangeable panel show it was parodying .
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:28pm annually retentive is an interesting one for me .
there 's loads of good stuff in there , but as a whole , i find it unsatisfying .
i 'm very pleased with how we pulled off the panel show aspect , from where i 'm standing it 's completely authentic .
the who do you think you are sequence is one of my favourites , and i loved the stuff i did with russell tovey .
i think there 's some very good work there .
i do a very funny loan company advert in one episode .
obviously in real life i would never consider entering the world of advertising .
flexiblerosterer asks : in human remains , there was a bit where the swinging b and b owner refers to his previous tendency to splash and dash .
who was responsible for this horribly evocative line ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:25pm i think , although i 'm not sure , that it was mine .
if that is not the case , i apologise wholeheartedly to julia .
funnily enough , we bought a kids slide for the garden the other day that was called dash n splash .

documents.title: `` of the people around today , there are none i have any regard or respect for ''
text: kirstyg asks : who were or are your biggest comedy/creative influences , and who do you admire most who is working today ?
also , much as i enjoy your alternative rob brydons , have you plans to write , or are you writing any character comedy of your own like marion and geoff ( which i really loved ) ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:23pm there are so many people whose work i admire .

in no particular order : barry humphries , don rickles , martin short , peter cook and dudley moore , victoria wood , jerry seinfeld , larry david , ronnies corbett and barker , joan rivers , bob newhart .
of the people around today , there are none i have any regard or respect for .
therooc asks : if you had to one , what was your favourite restaurant you dined at in both series of the trip ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:21pm il riccio , it 's part of the capri palace hotel .
it 's the one in the last episode of the trip to italy .
the food , the setting , the service , everything .
while we were filming the scene , gerard butler walked over to us ( in the middle of a take , i 'll have you know ) and said hi .
this added to the feeling that we were in an episode of the persuaders .
as you can imagine , this pleased my colleague no end .
notfoxed asks : who is your best friend ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:18pm his name is rhys john .
ant manbee asks : as a bristolian i always regarded welsh people as uneducated drunkards , was i correct in this assumption ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:17pm uneducated ?
how dare you .

documents.title: `` i 'd like to still be working , still making people laugh [ at 77 ] . and not to have succumbed to age-related memory loss . and to still be working , still making people laugh ''
text: kalidasa asks : rob i 'm exactly 37 years older than you at 77 , and i 'm a welsh-speaking welshman from a place called henllan near denbigh ¦ i 'm having a great time , what do you hope you will be doing when you are 77 ?
: ) guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:17pm i 'd like to still be working , still making people laugh .
and not to have succumbed to age-related memory loss .
and to still be working , still making people laugh .
id1781267 asks : rob what 's the best thing that 's ever happened to you ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:14pm having children .
and last friday , at the nando 's at southwark arches , i got free chicken wings and chips in a random act of kindness .
it 's hard to choose between the two .
mcderminator asks : abba , beatles , christians , doors , eagles , fleetwood mac ¦ what comes next in the sequence please , rob ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:13pm i do n't think we ever got that far .
genesis ?
yes , i think it was genesis .
again , one of my favourite things i 've ever done , that scene .
maidenover asks : 1 .
how did you feel about the summer fling arc in the trip to italy ?
personally it creeped me the eff out .
in trip to italy it was almost like you had to do an impression to communicate .
intentional ?
love you .
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:12pm i loved it .
i never get to do stuff like that normally .
and people 's reaction was amazing .
i think a lot of people think the show is simply a reality show .
i find that very funny .
someone said to my wife at the school gates : it must be a very difficult time for you .
re the impressions , that 's michael winterbottom 's fault , he eggs me on .
zachary johnston asks : rob , any plans for series 3 of the trip ?
i 'd love to see you and steve roaming santa barbara wine country or somewhere similar in the u.s .
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:10pm sounds great , but i think it would suit paul giamatti better than me .
bewilderedmark ask : did you manage to see the ireland vs wales game at the weekend ?
what are the welsh prospects for the world cup ?
also , could you ever envisage commentating a rugby match as al pacino ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:04pm i did n't as we were prepping future conditional which coincidentally is about to open at the old vic theatre .
our prospects are good .
i 'm going to the wales v australia match and then the final .
so i 'll see wales twice .
re pacino , it 's the dream we all share .
jack caramac asks : michelle and stephen in human remains , to me , feel like among the most complete and painfully accurate characters that you 've created .
where did the idea for them come from , and were there any particular people that they were based on ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:05pm thank you jack .
i love that series and that episode in particular .
the characters came from improvisation .
for steven , it was a voice and an attitude .
things i 'd observed in wales .
i like him a lot .
i feel he 's a computer , with a very big hard drive , but an inadequate processor .
alexiram asks : what did you think of paul whitehouse 's version of you on monday night ?
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:09pm relieved that he did n't highlight some of my many shortcomings , beyond a slightly uriah heep-y tendency-y .
i love harry and paul , so i was flattered to be included .
oops , there i go again .
i went to see the recording of a harry and chums show years and years ago , and paul was in it .
i 'd never seen him before .
he was talking to the audience a lot and was generally very confident .
i remember thinking : who the hell does this chap think he is ?
i have since reconsidered this view .
ianjohnsonnz asks : hi rob .
i do n't want to catch you off-guard with a question .
i 'd like you to answer a question of your choosing .
whatever you like .
surprise me !
guardian contributor robbrydon 02 september 2015 3:09pm thanks ianjohnsonnz .
rob , who was the first person you asked for an autograph from ?
well , ian , it was tony gubba .

documents.title: rob is with us now
text: here he is at guardian towers : beaumont-thomas

documents.title: post your questions for rob brydon
text: initially known from voiceovers for the likes of tango and tesco , rob brydon 's lilting voice has made him one of the best-known welshmen in the country but of course it 's his other voices that have made him truly famous .

be it the hilariously tiny tones of his small man in a box ' , to the variously smooth and spluttering takes on al pacino , michael caine and others , brydon darts around personae like a happy terrier .

he 's brought his malleability to bear on everything from lighthearted game shows to the melancholy sitcom marion and geoff , and his comic sparring with steve coogan in a cock and bull story as well as two series of the trip .
next up is a stint on the london stage , in future conditional , a to comedy about the intense pressures and bizarre foibles of the british education system .
as it opens this week at the old vic , brydon is joining us to answer your questions in a live webchat from 3pm bst onwards on wednesday 2 september .
post yours in the comments section below , and he 'll answer as many as possible .

bulletin.text: The impression-addicted actor joined us to answer your questions find out his favourite swimming stroke, whether he's glad that he played Uncle Bryn, what it was like working with Matthew Warchus at the Old Vic and more.
